markdownRemark.html:
Stacks

The stack is an abstract data type with the following operations:

  • push(key): adds the key to the collection
  • key top(): returns most recently-added key
  • key pop(): removes and returns most recently-added key()

These operations are already supported by arrays and linked lists. So arrays are a trivial way to implement a stack. We can also use linked lists. We can extend linked lists as long as we have memory available but we incur the overhead of storing pointers as well. Stacks are implementing a LIFO (Last In, First Out)

Queues

The queue is an abstract data type with the following operations:

  • enqueue(key): adds the key to the collection
  • dequeue(key): removes and returns leas recently added key

Queues implement a FIFO (First In, First out) type of service. One way is to implement list with linked list (with tail pointer).

We can also implement the queue with an array when the array is implemented as a circular buffer. When we deque, the imaginary start of the array is at index 1, then at index 2 and so fort. Then we can use indexes 0, and then 1 to store new elements. We can store a read and write index. When the read and the write index are the same that the queue is empty. The drawback of the array is that the dimension of the array is fixed.

The deque operation is implemented as a pop_front in a doubly linked list.
